awd_titl_txt: Rethinking Mathematics Classroom Observations: Connecting Interactions, Student Outcomes, and Teacher Practice
awd_abstract_narration:
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Funded by the EHR Core Research Program, this project addresses the need for the development of and research about a near real-time observation tool to improve mathematics classrooms. The observation tool will provide information about the kinds of student interactions in mathematics classrooms that are known to predict student outcomes. The level of detail obtained through the tool will be sufficient to capture different ways in which students participate, as well as produce data that teachers can use to inform and improve their teaching practices. Research on the use of this new tool will provide knowledge and build theory on how teachers' use of the feedback provided by this tool influences their practice, what student interactions in K-12 mathematics classrooms are occurring, and how the student interactions may connect to student outcomes. 

The project focuses on producing data about the value and usefulness of the information provided by a near real-time observational tool that tracks student participation and teacher support of students' participation. The results will inform the potential next step of promoting large-scale use of the tool by teachers, principals, school district leaders, and researchers to inform and improve teacher learning, teaching practices, and student outcomes. Results from the project will: show how to feasibly produce near real-time information about classroom interaction; produce a tool that can support teachers, principals, district leaders, and researchers in efforts to improve teaching and learning; and provide specific evidence about how such an observational tool can influence teacher learning and practice. Student participation with others around mathematical ideas and students' perceived competence about their abilities are important for both immediate learning outcomes and long-term participation in mathematics. Although no single instrument can address all variables that influence learning and teaching, this tool will move the field forward by focusing on a bounded set of classroom interaction features that research shows are predictive of student outcomes for diverse schools and student populations. This project will provide professional development opportunities to graduate students, pre-service teachers, and in-service teachers in Southern California and results will be disseminated to educators and other researchers. The findings have the potential to support teachers' efforts to provide each student with equitable opportunities to participate and learn.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed and tested a real-time observation measure (SPOT: Student Participation Observation Tool) for elementary mathematics classrooms that fronts student participation and captures teacher interaction in support of student participation. This tool is based on existing research that shows strong relationships between student participation that involves students' explaining the details of their ideas and engaging with the ideas of others and student learning outcomes and was developed to be more useful to practitioners and researchers than currently available measures. While the measure provides data that teachers can use to inform and improve their teaching practices and that researchers can use in research on teaching and learning, the measure also has potential for use by principals, instructional coaches, and school district leaders. The iterative process of developing and testing included fine-tuning the measure and investigating how teachers, coaches and school leaders use the resulting data to inform and guide their practice. The participants included collaborators from multiple districts in the Southern California area who varied in their approach to mathematics instruction.

The classroom observation measure developed in this project has multiple innovative features.  It captures (1) student participation that research shows is significantly related to student learning outcomes (to maximize the chances of the feedback from the measure being productive for influencing student learning), (2) the disciplinary details of student participation and teacher support moves (to track how students' ideas develop in the classroom setting, and to enable a deeper understanding of classroom practice), (3) the participation of individual students (to gain insights into the variability in participation among students in the classroom, and, consequently, help teachers make decisions about their instruction according to the needs of individual students, subgroups, and the entire classroom), (4) student participation and teacher moves in relation to each other (to clarify the types of teacher moves that support student participation, and to support teacher inquiry and reflection about their practices), and (5) student participation and teacher support moves across different phases and participation settings in the lesson (to provide insights into how student participation is situated within the social and temporal contexts of a lesson). The data from the measure can be used to create user-friendly pictorial representations of the data about student participation and teacher support moves which are intended to help teachers make sense of their practice and enable conversations that support crafting classroom practice that is responsive to students and their developing mathematical ideas.

Implementation of the observation measure in multiple schools and elementary grade levels showed that teachers used the observation data conversations to reflect about student explaining and engaging with each other's mathematical ideas in their classrooms, and to craft adaptations to their practice (existing practice, potential practice, and new practices to be implemented). Teachers made productive use of the observation data regardless of the prevalence and type of student participation that occurred in a teacher's classroom, showing that the observation measure promoted deep reflection among teachers regardless of existing student participation in their classrooms.

The results of this study show that a real-time classroom observation measure of student participation - one that focuses on dimensions of student participation shown to relate to students' learning outcomes - can support teacher learning and inform teachers' thinking and actions related to their instructional practices.
